Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
Award.AbstractNarration: This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This project adds to our knowledge of microbiomes, the communities of microorganisms that are in constant contact with most animals. Prior research on these microbiomes has shown that some microbes are associated with dietary changes and/or diseases but we have a limited understanding of how the gut microbiome affects behavior. Using the nematode worm C. elegans as a model system, this project seeks to characterize differences in microbiome composition during development and between males and females. It will further determine to what extent the microbiome affects behaviors and the neural signals that encode them. By focusing on mate choice and mating success-based behavior, this research will further explain the complex interactions of gut microbes with host tissues and subsequent behavioral changes. The Fellow will curate a network among scientists and teachers to develop educational (K-12) programming. These activities seek to improve scientistsâ€™ communication skills while providing hands-on, research-based scientific resources to educators and students from diverse communities who are often underrepresented in scientific disciplines. <br/> <br/>Microbiome studies are notoriously underpowered and what comprises a microbiome is inconsistently defined across laboratories. Therefore, this project will use a model microbiota, termed CeMbio, and its natural host, C. elegans, to facilitate reproducibility and collaborative efforts to characterize the effects of the microbiome on host biology. It seeks to integrate signals from microbial communities into neuronal circuitry and subsequent animal behavior. The Fellow will integrate large-scale genetic and metabolomic analyses with whole-brain calcium imaging from single-animal neural networks and small-population mating behavior studies. The project will address 1) how microbial colonization differs between males and females, 2) what molecular changes occur upon colonization in each sex, and 3) how colonization with a complex microbiota elicits differential behavioral patterns and neural circuitry. The Fellow seeks to understand if female- or male-specific behaviors and/or reproductive isolation can be caused, in part, by microbes. The Fellow will collaborate with expert mentors, attend conferences, and develop skills in computational and behavioral neuroscience. The Fellow will also develop a network of scientists and educators to bring research-based science lessons to local classrooms in the San Diego area by providing instructional tools and resources to teachers.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project sought to understand sex-specific differences in the microbiomes of C. elegans. The fellow, Dr. Molly Matty, sought to use these differences as a foundation for understanding the influence of complex microbiomes on animal behavior and physiology. This work was performed during her postdoctoral fellowship at the Salk Institute in San Diego, CA. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the scope of this project changed quite drastically due to the lack of laboratory time, open space, and available collaborators. However, the fellow followed through on understanding the foundational influence of hunger on animal behavior. We showed that C. elegans behave differently when deprived of food using a defined signaling pathway through which intestinal status is integrated by transcription factors HLH-30 and MML-1, which  together lead to the production of the small peptide INS-31, which is received by neurons expressing the insulin receptor DAF-2. This pathway is necessary for animals to shift their foraging strategy to increase food searching. Put simply, when animals are hungry, they are more willing to partake in riskier strategies to find food. This work resulted in a first-author publication in the journal PLoS Genetics, presentations at virtual conferences, and a tenure-track faculty position at the University of Portland.

Preliminary work, completed funded by the NSF PRFB, allowed the fellow to perform 16S microbiome sequencing on C. elegans raised on a complex microbiota. These experiments led to one recently submitted publication, authored by an undergraduate mentee, which describes the identity and function of a skin microbiome in C. elegans (the first to do so). The second round of 16S sequencing revealed something also quite unique ? that the composition of the gut microbiome of C. elegans is similar between the two sexes, but that exposure to male C. elegans shifts the hermaphrodite microbiome to resemble the males. These studies merit additional studies, but are intriguing and will be a future project for the Matty lab.

With support from the NSF, the fellow was able to attend a Woods Hole course (delayed one year due to the Covid-19 pandemic) to explore cutting edge approaches to understand neural systems and behavior. Through this course, the fellow developed skills and collaborations that supported her growth as an independent scientist. The fellow was also able to purchase critical software and simple dissecting microscopes necessary to perform research at home during the Covid-19.

As part of her broader impacts, the fellow initiated a virtual Scientific Research Educator Network (Sci-REN) in San Diego, CA. This event provided K-12 educators with hands-on lesson plans written by researchers. Those lesson plans can be accessed by anyone at scirenplans.com. Although entirely virtual, the Networking event still included about 20 researchers and 60 educators. The groundwork has been laid for SciREN-San Diego, although it was difficult to build consistent frameworks for leadership and institutional support.

 In additional impacts of broad relevance, the fellow mentored one high school student and one undergraduate student as they performed preliminary experiments seeking to understand the goals of this NSF proposal. Both of these students are women of color and still in science. One of these students is a current NSF GRFP fellow at Stanford and has a publication submitted to the journal mSpectrum. Their findings serve as the foundation for the research performed in the Matty lab, in which we explore the effects of a complex microbiome on C. elegans behavior. Without this fellowship and the opportunity to mentor these students, the fellow would not have earned a tenure-track faculty position and would not have had the foundation for her lab.

The fellow also used the time and support from the NSF PRFB to build additional support networks for young students in STEM. She started Virtual Active Science Engagement, VASE, which sought to unveil the hidden curriculum of academic science. This virtual mentoring group was provided, free of charge, to over 60 international undergraduates, most of whom identify as underrepresented in STEM. The work of this project was presented at a national conference.

In summary, the NSF PRFB was critical to the success of the fellow. She was able to be creative with her research, support students within and beyond her own laboratory space, and develop her own research program as an independent tenure-track faculty member at a primarily undergraduate institution. Her lab at the University of Portland is continuing the work of her NSF PRFB. Thank you!
